conclusion: When the two airborne objects (A and B) are lowered so that they touch the blocks already standing on the tray (C, D, E and F), gravity will simply pull A straight down until it rests on top of C-D, and B straight down until it rests on top of E-F.

conclusion: A ends up resting like a beam across C-D and B rests across E-F.

premise: If either pair of supports were too narrow or if A or B were placed off-centre, the corresponding supports would tip and the supported object would fall.
conclusion: With the positions shown in the picture each “beam” lands stably.
Gravity produces a vertical downward force on every object.

premise: As A and B descend they make first contact with the top surfaces of C-D and E-F, respectively.
conclusion: The normal forces from those tops counterbalance the weight of A and B, stopping their downward motion.

premise: Because each pair of supports is wide enough to keep the beam-like object’s centre of mass above the base polygon of the supports.

conclusion: Objects C, D, and E did not fall, while object F fell.
